Fig. 1 Schematic of the Preparation of Fe/C@NC-350/500 from Isostructural Iron-MOFs Precursors: (a) MOFs Precursors, (b) Pyrolysis Process. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Three-dimensional mass spectrogram of pyrolysis. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 The XRD patterns of Fe/C-K@NC-X samples. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TEM images of (a) Fe/C-K@NC-500, (b) Fe/C-K@NC-350/500, (c) Fe/C-K@NC-600, (d) Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of (e) Fe/C-K@NC-500, (f) Fe/C-K@NC-350/500. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) The Fe 2p XPS spectra of Fe/C-K@NC-X; (b) The C 1 s XPS spectra of Fe/C-K@NC-350/500; (c) The N 1 s XPS spectra of Fe/C-K@NC-X. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 CO2-TPD of Fe/C-K@NC-X catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 H2-TPR of Fe/C-K@NC-X catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The XRD patterns of Fe/C-K@NC-X after reaction. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 The Fe 2p XPS spectra of Fe/C-K@NC-X after reaction. Shanghai Key Laboratory of Multiphase Materials Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 People’s Republic of China Converting carbon dioxide into lower olefins (C2 =-C4 =) through hydrogenation is a crucial chemical reaction that allows for the use of CO2 as carbon source in the production of foundational chemicals. Herein, nitrogen-doped carbon-coated iron-based catalysts were obtained by pyrolysis NH2-MIL-88B under N2 atmosphere. The results show that the catalyst morphology, particle size and Fe phase structure can be controlled by changing the pyrolysis conditions. As the temperature rises, the structure starts to deteriorate, resulting in a gradual increase in the iron content and particle size. Fe3O4 and Fe3C phases appeared in the 350/500 °C two-stage pyrolysis, and the two-stage pyrolysis could effectively alleviate the structural collapse of MOFs precursors during the pyrolysis process. With the catalyst obtained by 350/500 °C two-stage pyrolysis, the conversion of CO2 could reach 35.1% and the selectivity of light olefins reached 37.7% (340 °C, 3 MPa, and GHSV= 5000 mL gcat −1 h−1). Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Olefins NH2-MIL-88B Fe/C-K@NC composite Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The current rise in CO2 emissions poses significant challenge to environmental concerns, including ocean acidification and climate change [1–5]. The thermo-catalytic conversion of CO2 into high-value fuels and chemicals, such as olefins, aromatics, and gasoline, has garnered widespread attention as one of the most practical methods for reducing CO2 emissions [6–9]. Light olefins (C2-C4) are crucial chemical raw materials used in the production of synthetic plastics and polymers. Consequently, there has been an increasing emphasis on studying CO2 hydrogenation as viable method for generating these crucial components [10–17]. The hydrogenation of carbon dioxide to light olefins can be broadly categorized into two routes: (1) the methanol intermediate route, and (2) the direct reverse water gas shift (RWGS) coupled Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) [18–21]. In the realm of direct CO2 hydrogenation to olefins, Fe-based catalysts are particularly advantageous due to their abundant reserves, affordability, and the two-step reaction of Fe3O4 and FeCx in RWGS and FTS, which serve as the active phase [22–26]. Based on the reaction mechanism that Fe3O4 and FeCx are the active components of reverse water gas shift and Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, few scholars have begun to design and synthesize catalyst containing FeOx coupled with FeCx or easily carbonized FeOx for CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins [27]. In terms of adding promoter, it's noteworthy that CO2, functioning as an acidic gas, tends to preferentially adsorb onto alkaline sites. Alkali metals (K, Na) are added to Fe-based catalysts to promote the adsorption of CO2 [18]. At the same time, alkali metals can provide electrons to the d orbital of Fe to stabilize the FeCx active phase, inhibit excessive hydrogenation of olefins [9,18,28]. Consequently, this multifaceted interaction contributes to an improved CO2 conversion rate and enhanced selectivity towards olefins. Recent studies have explored the use of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as sacrificial templates or precursors for the creation of porous carbon supports through pyrolysis, resulting in the production of metal nanoparticles embedded within carbon matrix [29–37]. The pyrolysis process typically involves direct heating in an inert gas, such as N2, leading to the formation of highly dispersed nanoparticles encapsulated within porous carbon matrix. During the initial phase of pyrolysis, the organic ligands decompose and evaporate into the gas phase, while the remaining components form porous carbonaceous matrix at higher temperatures [38]. By adjusting the pyrolysis temperature or pyrolysis time and other conditions, the various porosity and thickness of the carbon layer as well as the morphology and carbonization process of the metal nanoparticles can be easily regulated [39]. Cho et al. derived iron carbides by pyrolyzing MIL-100(Fe) and adjusting the pyrolysis temperature and holding time, which have high catalytic activity for FTS [40]. Building upon the aforementioned investigation, we present the Fe-based catalysts derived from the pyrolysis of NH2-MIL-88B(Fe) as the precursor, depicted in Fig. 1. The pyrolysis conditions were established based on the properties of the NH2-MIL-88B pyrolysis process, with differences in the size, physical phase, and structure of the Fe phase obtained under varying pyrolysis conditions being examined. The highly active CO2 hydrogenation catalysts, featuring FeOx and FeCx as the primary physical phases, were prepared through a two-stage pyrolysis approach. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of NH2-MIL-88B 1.47 g FeCl3-6 H2O was mixed with 0.984 g NH2-BDC (2-aminoterephthalic acid) in 60 mL N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), sonicated and dispersed for 1 h, then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (200 mL) and placed in an oven to crystallize at 120 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the solid was washed three times with methanol and DMF, followed by centrifugation and oven-drying at 80 °C overnight. The resulting brown solid NH2-MIL-88B was collected. 2.1.2 Preparation of Fe/C-K@NC-X A quantity of NH2-MIL-88B(Fe) was placed in a tube furnace and heat treated under N2 atmosphere from room temperature to the target temperature with the rate of 2 °C min−1 for 4 h. The resulting black powder solid was designated Fe/C@NC-X (X is the target pyrolysis temperature). Fe/C@NC-350/X was obtained by heating to 350 °C with the rate of 2 °C min−1 in N2 atmosphere and holding for 2 h, then raising the temperature to the target temperature with the rate of 2 °C min−1 and holding for 4 h. Fe/C-K@NC-X were prepared by the initial wet impregnation (IWI) method. An aqueous solution of K2CO3 (a certain amount of K2CO3 dissolved in an equal volume of water just wetted with MOFs) was dropped into the Fe/C@NC-X samples and the obtained samples was dried at 80 °C overnight to obtain Fe/C-K@NC-X. 2.2 Catalytic performance evaluation The catalytic CO2 hydrogenation reaction was measured in a 10 mm inner diameter stainless steel fixed bed reactor and the catalyst (fixed charge of 0.24 g) was reduced with pure H2 (20 mL min−1) at 400 °C for 5 h prior to the reaction. After reduction, gas mixture with H2/CO2/N2 ratio of 69/23/8 was introduced into the reactor under reaction conditions of P = 3 MPa, T = 340 °C and gas space velocity (GHSV) = 5000 mL gcat −1 h−1. The reaction products were first condensed by cooling circulating water to collect the water vapor and liquid hydrocarbons in the product. The remaining reaction gases were detected by on-line gas chromatography (Techcomp GC7900). CO2, CO, CH4, and N2 were analyzed on TCD detector with TDX–01 packed column, hydrocarbons and carbon hydroxides were analyzed on FID detector with HP-PLOT/Al2O3 capillary column. CO2 conversion and product selectivity were calculated on the basis of total carbon atom preservation. The carbon balance exceeded 95.0% for each test after quantification of all other products. CO2 conversion was calculated by Eq. (1). (1) X CO 2 % = n co 2 in − n co 2 out n co 2 in × 100 % n co 2 in and n co 2 out represented the molar fraction of CO2 in and out the reactor. CO selectivity was calculated by Eq. (2): (2) S co % = n co out n co 2 in − n co 2 out × 100 % n co out represented the molar fraction of CO out the reactor. The selectivity of hydrocarbon in the whole hydrocarbon was calculated by Eq. (3): (3) S C i H j % = n C i H j × i ∑ i = 1 N n C i H j × i × 100 % Space time yield of olefins (STY, mmol/gcat/h) was calculated by Eq. (4): (4) S TY = F CO 2 × X CO 2 × ( 1 − S CO ) × S olefins 22.4 * m cat F CO 2 represents the molar flow rate of inlet CO2. 2.3 Catalysts characterization X-ray diffraction was performed on Bruker D8 Advance A25 X-ray diffractometer (XRD) with Cu Kα beams scanned by a graphite monochromator (λ = 1.54056 Å). The tube voltage and current were 40 kV and 40 mA. The Fe species in the catalyst were analyzed in the scan range of 5–80° at step size of 5° min−1. The Agilent 725 ICP-OES was used to determine the elemental content of the samples. The specific surface area (BET), pore volume (BJH) and pore distribution (DFT) of the catalysts were determined by nitrogen physisorption experiments on ASAP-2020 automated gas adsorption system from Micromeritics. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, ZEISS Gemini 300) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI TF 20) were used to study the microscopic morphology and nanostructure of the catalysts. The samples were prepared by immersing the copper mesh coated with carbon film in ethanol solution of the samples and drying at room temperature. CO2 programmed temperature desorption (CO2-TPD), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were tested on Micromeritics Auto Chem II 2920. 50 mg of catalyst was first reduced in the reactor with 20 mL min−1 H2 for 5 h and then subjected to CO2-TPD experiments. The impurity was removed by pretreatment in pure Ar for 2 h, the system was cooled to room temperature and CO2/He mixed gas was passed through for adsorption for 0.5 h. Then the CO2 physically adsorbed on the catalyst surface was removed by purging with Ar. TCD signals were recorded at 10 °C min−1 from 50 °C to 700 °C. The H2-TPR test was conducted after the samples were heated at 200 °C with Ar (50 mL min−1) for 1.0 h. After cooling to room temperature, the gas was switched to 10% H2/Ar and the samples were heated to 700 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 for analysis. The chemical state of the catalyst surface atoms was characterized using an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (ThermoFisher, ESCALAB 250Xi), where the excitation source was Al Kα. The binding energy data were charge corrected using an energy standard of C 1 s = 284.80 eV binding energy. A thermogravimetric-mass spectrometer (TG-MS, Thermo plus EV2/ thermo mass photo) was used to analyze the changes in the NH2-MIL-88B pyrolysis process. The experiments were carried out under N2 atmosphere at a temperature increase the rate of 10 °C min−1 in the range of 30–1000 °C to obtain information on the pyrolysis properties of MOFs under N2 and the mass spectra of the gaseous products escaping from the decomposition. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Pyrolysis process characteristics of NH2-MIL-88B Taking the mass-to-charge ratio(m/z) as the x-axis, the temperature as the y-axis and the ion current intensity as the z-axis, the three-dimensional mass spectrum of the pyrolysis process of NH2-MIL-88B can be obtained, as shown in Fig. 2. It can be seen from Fig. 2 that the m/z of the main gaseous products during the pyrolysis of NH2-MIL-88B is concentrated in the range of 10–80 and mainly concentrated in the pyrolysis carbonization stage (200–700 °C). In the pre-pyrolysis stage (30–200 °C), the main mass spectrum peaks are m/z = 17 (OH-), 18 (H2O), indicating that this stage is dehydration stage and a large amount of surface adsorbed water escapes. A large number of gaseous products were observed in the pyrolytic carbonation stage (200–700 °C), especially above 500 °C, with the main mass spectral peaks being m/z = 16, 17, 18, 26, 28, 30, 42, 44, 71. It is speculated that the gaseous products produced by the cracking of organic ligands, the most likely corresponding ion fragments are O-, OH-/NH3, H2O, C2H2, CO/C2H4, C2H6, C3H6, CO2, C₄H₉N. Among them, OH- and H2O are the escape of crystalline water and the rest of the peaks are ionized fragment peaks of organic ligands and CO2 [41]. This suggests that the mass loss during this stage is primarily attributed to the elimination of crystalline water and cleavage of organic ligands, while the residual organic matter participates in the formation of NH2-MIL-88B-derived carbon materials. The presence of m/z = 17, 28, and 30 at the high-temperature carbonization stage (700–1000 °C) indicates the continued cracking of a small amount of uncracked organic matter, in addition to the release of crystalline water during the cracking carbonization stage. A summary of the pyrolysis process for NH2-MIL-88B is depicted in Fig. S1. To limit the partial cracking of organic ligands and promote the formation of stable carbon skeleton, it was recommended to maintain control of the pyrolysis temperature above 500 °C. 3.2 Textural properties To examine the alterations in the physical properties of the MOFs precursors pre- and post-pyrolysis, the samples were characterized and assessed utilizing a fully automated adsorption analyzer for specific surface area and porosity. The results obtained are shown in Fig. S2 and Table 1. NH2-MIL-88B displayed significant N2 uptake at lower relative pressures, indicating the generation of microporous structure. In contrast, Fe/C-K@NC-X exhibits type IV isotherm with an H3 hysteresis loop and a hysteresis loop at P/P0 ≈ 0.6, indicating that Fe/C-K@NC-X has mesoporous structure [42,43]. When the pyrolysis temperature was increased to 500 °C, the specific surface area of NH2-MIL-88B was partially sacrificed, decreasing from 408.4 m2 g−1 to 22.1 m2 g−1. However, the two-stage pyrolysis (350/500 °C) partially alleviated the sacrifice of the specific surface area (down to 86.8 m2 g−1). The results of Fe/C-K@NC-600 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 were also comparable. The results indicate that two-stage pyrolysis can effectively mitigate the structural collapse during pyrolysis and slow down the loss of specific surface area. XRD patterns of NH2-MIL-88B(Fe) composites and Fe/C-K@NC-X obtained by pyrolysis at different temperatures in N2 atmosphere are presented in Fig. 3 and Fig. S3. By using the crystallographic information file (CIF) from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC) 647646, the NH2-MIL-88B(Fe) structure's X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was simulated [44]. The Fe/C-K@NC-500 obtained by pyrolysis at 500 °C is not yet carbonized and the majority of the composition is Fe3O4 (JCPDS#75–0033). The Fe/C-K@NC-600 obtained by increasing the pyrolysis temperature to 600 °C shows mainly peaks of singlet α-Fe (JCPDS#06–0696) and Fe3C (JCPDS#87–0722). The diffraction pattern of Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 shows the simultaneous presence of FeO (JCPDS#75–1550) and Fe3C (JCPDS#77–0255), while Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 shows the simultaneous presence of Fe3O4 and Fe3C peak. The results above demonstrate the critical impact of pyrolysis temperature on the composition of the Fe phase within Fe/C-K@NC-X. Specifically, the pyrolysis of NH2-MIL-88B yields iron oxides at lower temperatures, while the reduction and carburization processes begin to occur at higher pyrolysis temperatures [45]. The morphological transformations of the MOFs precursors prior to and following pyrolysis, along with the particle size, distribution of agglomeration, and thickness of the carbon layer enveloping the Fe/C-K@NC-X nanoparticles, were thoroughly analyzed through TEM and SEM. As shown in Fig. 4 and Fig. S3, NH2-MIL-88B shows typical hexagonal bipyramidal prism structure [46], and the sample is uniformly dispersed and the particle size is relatively uniform. However, the original structure and shape of NH2-MIL-88B in the sample after pyrolysis was destroyed and the particles were uniformly dispersed in the carbon matrix. As the pyrolysis temperature increased, the structure and shape were further destroyed and the surface of the particles became very rough. The particle interface boundary becomes blurred. The particle size distribution becomes wider, and the average particle size increases from 111.4 nm of Fe/C-K@NC-500–131.5 nm of Fe/C-K@NC-600. The particles obtained through pyrolysis at 600 °C are predominantly encapsulated by carbon matrix, which can be attributed to the high pyrolysis temperature. While iron nanoparticles are present on the surface of the carbon matrix, they constitute only a small fraction of the overall Fe particles. The carbon layer is relatively thick, resulting in severe particle agglomeration. The two-stage pyrolysis at 350/500 °C retained the original hexagonal bipyramidal prism structure of some MOFs, and the average particle size was smaller at 78.6 nm. At the same time, Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 also alleviated the structural collapse phenomenon due to two-stage pyrolysis. And compared with Fe/C-K@NC-X obtained by direct pyrolysis at 600 °C, the average particle size was reduced to 125 nm. In addition, the Fe3O4-Fe3C structure in the nitrogen-doped carbon layer in Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 was further confirmed by HR-TEM (Fig. 4e and f). The lattice spacings are 0.294 nm and 0.249 nm, corresponding to the Fe3O4(220) and Fe3C (200) crystal planes, respectively. The electron microscope images reveal that the two-stage pyrolysis not only mitigates the structural collapse during pyrolysis, but also results in smaller nanoparticle sizes and more concentrated size distribution in Fe/C-K@NC-350/500. Additionally, the electron microscopy results demonstrate the effectiveness of the two-stage pyrolysis in forming the Fe3O4-Fe3C structure during the pyrolysis of the MOFs precursor. 3.3 Surface chemistry and reduction behavior of the samples Fig. 5 displays the XPS characterization results of the Fe/C-K@NC-X catalyst, which reveal the chemical environment and valence state of each element in its framework structure. The XPS spectrum is decomposed into two binding energy regions, namely 705–720 eV for Fe 2p3/2 and 720–740 eV for Fe 2p1/2 [47] (Fig. 5a). The binding energy peaks at 709 and 722.6 eV belong to Fe2+ and the binding energy peaks at 711 and 724.6 eV belong to Fe3+ [48,49]. It can be seen from the Fig. 5b that the binding energies of 283.5 eV, 284.9 eV and 289.1 eV correspond to the C-C, C-N and CO signal peaks of C 1 s [49]. In addition, two obvious binding energy signal peaks were observed at 708.2 eV and 721.4 eV in the Fe 2p diagram, combined with the signal peak at 283.5 eV in the C 1 s XPS spectrum, indicating the presence of Fe3C phase on the catalyst surface [47]. No significant signal peaks of metallic Fe nanoparticles were detected in the spectrum, which may be attributed to their encapsulation by the porous carbon layer. The XPS spectrum revealed the presence of Fe2+ and Fe3+ phases on the surface of the catalyst. However, the XRD results indicated the absence of iron oxide in the Fe/C-K@NC-600 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 samples, indicating that the surface of the samples has been partially oxidized. This iron oxide is amorphous, and previous studies have identified it as iron monoxide (Fe1−xO) [50]. Fig. 5c depicts the photoelectron peak of N 1 s. The nitrogen source is derived from the amino group in the organic ligand (NH2-BDC). The chemical environment of the nitrogen element is relatively complex, including peaks for pyridine nitrogen, pyrrole nitrogen, and graphitic nitrogen. The corresponding binding energies are 398.5 eV, 400.5 eV and 401.1 eV [51], respectively. As the pyrolysis temperature increased, the pyridinic nitrogen content decreased and the graphitic nitrogen content increased, as shown in Table S1. It is believed that the presence of N can provide metal anchoring sites, thereby promoting the high dispersion of metals [52]. Specifically, pyridine-N provides coordination sites for atomic Fe in the form of FeNx, which can improve the CO2 hydrogenation activity of Fe-based catalysts [53]. The CO2-TPD characterization experiment was used to study the catalyst's adsorption capacity for CO2, as proper chemical adsorption is beneficial for the activation of CO2. As shown in Fig. 6, the CO2 desorption temperature is mainly concentrated at 100 °C. As the pyrolysis temperature increases, the Fe content in the catalyst increases, leading to a higher CO2 adsorption capacity. Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 exhibits the highest CO2 desorption temperature and the strongest CO2 adsorption capacity, suggesting a higher probability of carbon-carbon coupling during the reaction process [54], and higher C5+ selectivity in the final product of CO2 hydrogenation. The effect of different pyrolysis temperatures on the reducibility of iron-based catalysts was evaluated by H2-TPR. As shown in the Fig. 7, the reduction peaks of Fe/C-K@NC-500 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 are similar. There are two H2 consumption peaks, reflecting the gradual reduction of Fe3O4 to metal Fe (Fe3O4→FeO→Fe). The peak appearing in the range of 250–340 °C is the reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO, and the peak appearing in the range of 400–700 °C is the further reduction of FeO to α-Fe [15]. Iron carbide is more readily reduced than iron oxide, which causes the reduction peak of Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 to shift to a lower temperature. The small amount of Fe3C in Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 improves the reduction behavior of the iron catalyst. The peaks observed in the 350–400 °C range for the Fe/C-K@NC-600 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 catalysts are attributed to the hydrogenation of Fe3C to produce metallic Fe and methane [55,56], while Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 is at 400 − 700 °C also appeared the reduction peak of FeO further reduced to α-Fe. The reduced catalyst was characterized by XRD, and the results are shown in the Fig. S5. The peaks at 2θ= 44.7 of the catalysts Fe/C-K@NC-X obtained at four different pyrolysis temperatures belong to the (110) crystal plane of α-Fe. After reduction, the peak shapes of Fe/C-K@NC-600 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 become sharper compared to Fe/C-K@NC-500 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/500, respectively, due to the presence of α-Fe phase before reduction, indicating better crystallinity of elemental Fe. In the case of Fe/C-K@NC-350/500, the (110) diffraction peak of reduced Fe is sharper than that of Fe/C-K@NC-500 due to the small portion of Fe3C present. These results suggest that the two-stage pyrolysis process can better promote the reduction of Fe3O4, leading to the formation of the reactive phase Fe5C2 and enhancing the reactivity, which is consistent with the earlier H2-TPR results. 3.4 Characterization of the spent catalysts To further confirm the presence of active iron phase after the reaction, X-ray diffraction analysis was performed on the spent catalyst after a reaction time of 60 h, as shown in Fig. 8. Fe/C-K@NC-500 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 exhibited magnetite (Fe3O4) as the main phase. Additionally, χ-Fe5C2 diffraction peaks were observed, with peaks at 43.4°, 44°, and 45° attributed to Hägg carbide (χ-Fe5C2) [21,27], indicating the presence of this phase on the catalyst surface. These species were formed in situ during the reaction, consistent with previous conclusions and supporting the classical FTS mechanism [18]. The χ-Fe5C2 phase was more pronounced in the Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 catalyst, suggesting that the Fe3C in the new Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 catalyst is more favorable for the in-situ formation of Fe5C2 during the reaction process. The primary peaks in the X-ray diffraction patterns of Fe/C-K@NC-600 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 differ, primarily comprising Fe3C and χ-Fe5C2. Notably, the diffraction peak intensity of χ-Fe5C2 in Fe/C-K@NC-500 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 is significantly higher than that observed in Fe/C-K@NC-600 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/600. It has been reported [40,57] that the Fe3C phase exhibits lower activity in CO2 hydrogenation reactions compared to Fe5C2. Another significant contrast pertains to the presence of the Fe3O4 phase. Conversely, Fe/C-K@NC-600 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 waste catalysts essentially lack Fe3O4 diffraction peaks, which also contributes to CO2 catalytic activity. The surface morphology of the iron-based catalyst post-reaction was analyzed using XPS. In the Fig. 9, signal peaks of Fe5C2 at 707.0 eV and FeOx at 709.8 and 711.4 eV are observed in Fe/C-K@NC-500 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 [58,59]. In comparison to Fe/C-K@NC-500, Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 exhibits a more prominent peak at 708.0 eV, while FeOx shows a diminished peak at 710.0 eV, indicating an increased degree of carbonization. In the case of Fe/C-K@NC-600 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/600, signal peaks of Fe3C at 708.0 eV and FeOx at 709.8 and 711.4 eV were detected, confirming the presence of the Fe3O4 phase. Despite XRD characterization clearly indicating the absence of the FeOx phase between Fe/C-K@NC-600 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/600, this suggests that a small amount of FexC undergoes oxidation during samples transfer in the air prior to XPS measurement. These results further confirm that iron exists in different forms and exhibits different catalytic activities on spent catalysts. 3.5 CO2 hydrogenation performance Table 2 and Fig. 10 summaries the catalytic activity and product distribution on Fe/C-K@NC-X at T = 340 °C, P = 3.0 MPa and GHSV= 5000 mL gcat −1 h−1. In agreement with previous studies [10,18], the main products of CO2 conversion over these iron-based catalysts are CO and further hydrogenation of CO to hydrocarbons (i.e. CH4 and C2+ hydrocarbons). The carbon distribution of the CO hydrogenation products fits the Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) model of FTS. The Fe/C-K@NC-X catalysts obtained at different pyrolysis temperatures showed significant differences in product distribution, which can be attributed to variations in their structures and phases. Among them, Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 demonstrated the highest carbon dioxide conversion rate of 35.1% and light olefins selectivity of 37.7%. Previous reports have suggested that Fe3O4 and FeCx are active sites for RWGS and FTS reactions, respectively. Therefore, the high activity of Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 can be attributed to the synergistic effect of iron oxides and iron carbides produced by the two-stage pyrolysis, as well as the retained portion of the initial MOFs structure. The CO2 conversion rates of Fe/C-K@NC-500 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 were 32.2% and 25.5%, respectively, which are higher than the 23.4% of Fe/C-K@NC-600. Although the CO2-TPD results indicate that Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 has the highest CO2 adsorption capacity, according to previous research [18], the CO2 hydrogenation activity and final product selectivity are mainly determined by the rate and selectivity of the subsequent FTS step. The XRD results indicate that the formation of iron oxides is favored by pyrolysis at low temperatures such as 350 °C and 500 °C, while Fe3C is the main iron phase obtained by pyrolysis at 600 °C. As the pyrolysis temperature increases, the Fe content in the catalyst also increases. The experimental results suggest that the difference in CO2 conversion rate on the catalyst is due to the combined effects of Fe content, Fe phase composition, and subsequent FTS rate. In our study, the Fe3O4-FeCx active phase was directly designed for CO2 hydrogenation by pyrolyzing MOFs, in which the active phase was wrapped in a carbon layer. According to the XRD results of the catalyst after the reaction, a small number of Fe3C characteristic peaks appeared in the catalyst after the reaction. It shows that compared with traditional oxide supports, carbon material supports and Fe are prone to form part of Fe3C in situ or during the reaction process. According to previous studies [60], the conversion energy barrier of the CO intermediate generated by RWGS on Fe3C alone is relatively high, and it tends to desorb to form CO rather than further converting to hydrocarbons, which directly leads to the high selectivity of CO. This conclusion is more obvious in Fe/C-K@NC-600 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/600. The most iron phases in Fe/C-K@NC-600 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 before and after the reaction are Fe3C. The selectivity of all hydrocarbon products of Fe/C-K@NC-600 and Fe/C-K@NC-350/600 is lower than that of Fe/C-K@NC-500, with most of the products being CO and selectivity over 58%. This conclusion is similar to previous studies in which honeycomb-structured graphene (HSG)-loaded Fe NPs [61] and iron-based carbon-coated core-shell catalysts [62] were used for CO2-olefins reactions, with the selectivity of CO are 44% and 78.3%, respectively. Numerous studies have reported the conversion of carbon dioxide to light olefins, and several catalysts have been studied, as shown in Table S2. Fan et al. [63] studied the Cr2O3-SAPO-34 catalyst and reported CO2 conversion rate of 13%, light olefins selectivity of 61%, and light olefins STY of 3.6 mmol gcat −1 h−1. Guo et al. [39] reported that the N-K-600–0 catalyst achieved CO2 conversion rate of 43%, selectivity of light olefins of 27%, and STY of 4.7 mmol gcat −1 h−1. The CuFeO2 catalyst exhibited CO2 conversion rate of 18.1%, light olefins selectivity of 23.8%, and light olefins STY of 0.50 mmol gcat −1 h−1 [7]. Compared to these catalysts, the Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 catalyst shows promising results in terms of CO2 conversion, light olefins selectivity, and light olefins yield. Therefore, it could be a competitive alternative to the above catalysts for the conversion of carbon dioxide to light olefins. We conducted further investigations into the stability of Fe/C-K@NC-350/500 under 3 MPa (H2:CO2 = 3:1) with a space velocity of conditions of 5000 mL gcat −1 h−1 at 340 °C. After 60 h, the CO2 conversion rate remained consistently at 35% ( Fig. 11) Simultaneously, the selectivity for methane, and light olefins (C2 =-C4 =) held steady at 24% and 38%. Over the continuous reaction period, the catalyst's performance exhibited no significant changes, demonstrating its remarkable stability. 4 Conclusion Our study examined the impact of varying pyrolysis temperatures on the properties and efficacy of MOFs-derived Fe-based catalysts coated with carbon (Fe/C-K@NC-X). These catalysts, produced by direct pyrolysis of NH2-MIL-88B in N2, exhibited significant changes in carbonization, Fe composition, and particle size with different pyrolysis temperatures. With the increase of pyrolysis temperature, the initial structure of MOFs began to collapse, iron oxides were formed at low temperatures, and metal nanoparticles were well embedded in the generated carbon carriers. When the pyrolysis temperature is 600 °C, the obtained elemental Fe and Fe3C after reduction and carburizing are basically obtained, and the metal particles are partially sintered. The two-stage pyrolysis (350/500 °C) process enables the formation of Fe3O4-FeCx structure and maintain partially high specific surface area, which exhibits high catalytic activity in CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins (with CO2 conversion rate of 35.1% and light olefins selectivity of 37.7%). These findings shed light on potential strategies for controlling the structure and metal composition of catalysts through adjustments to pyrolysis conditions. Additionally, they offer insights into the active phase (FeOx-FeCx) that arise during CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins. coredata.dc:description: Converting carbon dioxide into lower olefins (C2 =-C4 =) through hydrogenation is a crucial chemical reaction that allows for the use of CO2 as carbon source in the production of foundational chemicals. Herein, nitrogen-doped carbon-coated iron-based catalysts were obtained by pyrolysis NH2-MIL-88B under N2 atmosphere. The results show that the catalyst morphology, particle size and Fe phase structure can be controlled by changing the pyrolysis conditions. As the temperature rises, the structure starts to deteriorate, resulting in a gradual increase in the iron content and particle size. Fe3O4 and Fe3C phases appeared in the 350/500 °C two-stage pyrolysis, and the two-stage pyrolysis could effectively alleviate the structural collapse of MOFs precursors during the pyrolysis process. With the catalyst obtained by 350/500 °C two-stage pyrolysis, the conversion of CO2 could reach 35.1% and the selectivity of light olefins reached 37.7% (340 °C, 3 MPa, and GHSV= 5000 mL gcat −1 h−1).
coredata.dc:title: Metal-organic framework-derived Fe3O4-FeCx catalyst for direct CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins
